name: Pricing
description: The PRC segment contains pricing information for healthcare services, procedures, and items. This segment supports healthcare financial management by providing detailed cost and pricing data including base prices, discounts, markup factors, effective dates, and billing rules. It is essential for revenue cycle management, contract pricing, and cost accounting in healthcare organizations.

cardinality.note: Multiple PRC segments can be used to specify different pricing structures for various scenarios

PRC.1.name: Primary Key Value - PRC
PRC.1.description: This field contains the primary key that uniquely identifies the pricing record. This is typically the procedure or service code for which pricing is being established.
PRC.1.generationHint: CPT, HCPCS, or internal service codes that require pricing information

PRC.2.name: Facility ID - PRC
PRC.2.description: This field identifies the healthcare facility or organization for which this pricing applies. Allows for facility-specific pricing structures.
PRC.2.generationHint: Facility identifiers allow location-specific pricing variations

PRC.3.name: Department
PRC.3.description: This field identifies the department or service line for which this pricing applies.

PRC.4.name: Valid Patient Classes
PRC.4.description: This field specifies the patient classes or types for which this pricing applies.
PRC.4.generationHint: Patient classification affects pricing structure and billing rules

PRC.5.name: Price
PRC.5.description: This field contains the base price or charge for the service or item.
PRC.5.generationHint: Base pricing amount format: NNNN.NN^USD - can have multiple prices for different scenarios

PRC.6.name: Formula
PRC.6.description: This field contains a formula or calculation method used to determine the final price based on various factors.

PRC.7.name: Minimum Quantity
PRC.7.description: This field specifies the minimum quantity that must be ordered to qualify for this pricing.
PRC.7.generationHint: Minimum order quantities for bulk pricing: 1, 10, 50, 100

PRC.8.name: Maximum Quantity
PRC.8.description: This field specifies the maximum quantity that can be ordered at this pricing level.
PRC.8.generationHint: Maximum quantities for tiered pricing structures

PRC.9.name: Minimum Price
PRC.9.description: This field contains the minimum price that can be charged regardless of discounts or calculations.
PRC.9.generationHint: Floor price to ensure minimum revenue: format NNNN.NN

PRC.10.name: Maximum Price
PRC.10.description: This field contains the maximum price that can be charged regardless of markups or calculations.
PRC.10.generationHint: Ceiling price for regulatory compliance or contract limits

PRC.11.name: Effective Start Date
PRC.11.description: This field contains the date when this pricing becomes effective.
PRC.11.generationHint: When pricing takes effect - important for contract and billing accuracy

PRC.12.name: Effective End Date
PRC.12.description: This field contains the date when this pricing expires or is no longer valid.
PRC.12.generationHint: Pricing expiration date - after this date, default or new pricing applies

PRC.13.name: Price Override Flag
PRC.13.description: This field indicates whether this price can be overridden by authorized personnel.
PRC.13.generationHint: Price flexibility controls for billing staff

PRC.14.name: Billing Category
PRC.14.description: This field categorizes the pricing for billing and reporting purposes.
PRC.14.generationHint: Billing categories help organize revenue streams and reporting

PRC.15.name: Chargeable Flag
PRC.15.description: This field indicates whether this item or service is chargeable to the patient or insurance.
PRC.15.generationHint: Controls whether service generates patient charges

PRC.16.name: Active/Inactive Flag
PRC.16.description: This field indicates whether this pricing record is currently active and should be used.
PRC.16.generationHint: Controls whether pricing is available for use in billing systems

PRC.17.name: Cost
PRC.17.description: This field contains the actual cost to provide the service or item, used for cost accounting and margin analysis.
PRC.17.generationHint: Internal cost for margin analysis and financial reporting

PRC.18.name: Charge on Indicator
PRC.18.description: This field indicates what triggers the application of this charge or pricing.
PRC.18.generationHint: Charging trigger determines when pricing is applied in workflow

notes: PRC segments are essential for healthcare revenue cycle and pricing management
Primary Key Value (PRC.1) is required to identify the service being priced
Effective date ranges ensure pricing accuracy over time
Multiple pricing structures can exist for different facilities, departments, or patient types
Price override flags provide flexibility while maintaining controls
Cost information supports margin analysis and financial planning

dataConsistency.dateValidation: Effective end date (PRC.12) should be after start date (PRC.11)
dataConsistency.priceValidation: Minimum price (PRC.9) should be less than maximum price (PRC.10)
dataConsistency.quantityValidation: Minimum quantity (PRC.7) should be less than maximum quantity (PRC.8)
dataConsistency.costValidation: Cost (PRC.17) should be less than price (PRC.5) for positive margins

businessRules.pricingIntegrity: Prices should be reasonable for the service type and market
businessRules.dateManagement: Overlapping pricing periods should be handled appropriately
businessRules.authorizationRules: Override flags should align with organizational policies
businessRules.billingCompliance: Pricing should comply with insurance contracts and regulations
businessRules.costControl: Price floors and ceilings should prevent billing errors

messageFlow.workflow: Usually part of master file maintenance messages for pricing distribution
